Ronald L. Rivest

Biography

Ronald L. Rivest born 6 of may, 1947 in Schenectady, New York, US, is an American computer scientist, cryptographer and an institute professor at MIT. He is one of the three cowinners of the Turing Award in 2002, along with Leonard M. Adleman and Adi Shamir. They have been rewarded for their patented “Cryptographic Communication System and Method”, or RSA encryption. His work was basically about the discipline of algorithms and combinatorics, cryptography, election integrity and machine learning.
He is the inventor of symmetric key encryption algorithms Rivest Cipher: RC2, RC4, RC5, RC6; also known as Ron’s Codes.

Career and Research

Rivest got his bachelor’s degree in 1069 in mathematics, earned at Yale University. Later he got a doctorate in 1974 in computer science from Standfort University, followed the attendance at MIT as member of Theory of Computation Group, where he met Leonard M. Adleman and Adi Shamir. He also became the Viterbi Professor of Computer Science at MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory. Three years later he produced his first public-key encryption system using digital signatures. In 1983 they founded RSA Data Security and VeriSign, a digital certification system on the Internet many people use to encrypt and secure mails and digital transactions.
In 2006 Rivest published its ThreeBallot voting system which includes the ability for the voter to verify that the vote gets properly recorded, respecting their privacy.
Rivest has also been elected to numerous Awards along with Turing’s, such as the U.S National Academy of Engineering, the U.S National Academy of Sciences, the Association for Computing Machinery, the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Koji Kobayashi Computers and Communications Award and many more.
